name: Lazarus Group ATT&CK Patterns
description: The tactics, techniques and procedures used by the Lazarus Group as part of their global operations

techniques.comment: Lazarus group used Windows Command Shell in their operations, allowing them to execute arbitrary commands.
Lazarus group used the Telegram service's uncommon ports for their command and control communications.
Lazarus group's malware includes remote access trojans (RATs) named 'NineRAT' and 'DLRAT'.
Lazarus group used the vulnerability of CVE-2021-44228 (Log4Shell) for initial access and to carry out their operations.
Lazarus group conducted extensive system fingerprinting and collected credentials with the help of utilities such as ProcDump and MimiKatz.
Lazarus group created an additional local user account on the systems they infiltrated, granting it administrative privileges.
The malware used by Lazarus group requires a user to run or directly interact with it in order for execution to occur.
Lazarus undertook several methods to collect user data, for instance by running commands such as 'whoami' and 'getmac'.
Lazarus exploited the CVE-2021-44228 vulnerability, using direct access to carry out an information gathering reconnaissance mission.
Lazarus used Telegram channels to communicate, this allows them to evade network and host-based detection measures.
Lazarus performed OS credential dumping using ProdDump and Mimikaz tools.
Lazarus created a URL file in the Startup directory to maintain persistence for their follow-up payloads.
Lazarus is manipulating system services by modifying service binary paths, executing malicious codes as services.
Several commands were executed to gather system information as a part of the reconnaissance. The gathered data includes user info, system version, antivirus product info etc.
Used to identify installed defensive solutions on victim's machines.
Lazarus successfully exploited the Log4j vulnerability for initial access and to deploy several pieces of malware.
Initial infection was carried out by tricking users into clicking on malicious linkage which is attached to spear-phishing mails or exists in malicious websites.
